text: news of the ride came as no surprise for
Abdullah Kim the 39 year old father of
two was at home with his family when he
heard a commotion outside Abdul told me
he was the first person to call the
police and this is why this is the first
riot in Singapore in four decades all
sparked by the death of an Indian
national who was knocked down by a bust
here was hammering we got bare hands on
the coach himself and they have a lot of
noise there was a lot of cheering did a
lot of screaming also and they were
throwing waters on the roadside this
shop owner had to close her store when
the violence broke out she and her

the writers could break in the fight is
very big they're freaking the cars and
then they are turning the policeman's
vehicle then they're putting fire on
them last night all of this produce was
scattered on the ground outside of their
store the owners say the rioters used
these vegetables as weapons to push back
the police they believed they could have
lost up to fifteen thousand dollars in
lost produce and sales but it's not just
the economic impact
they fear there could be long-term
issues for the Indian community because
some of the people do like this either
way we are not doing that in say we
didn't participate in that but we also
will be affected because of them hate
messages on websites like these show why
he and others are worried that
Singapore's government isn't convinced I
don't want to to cast this as you know
foreign worker versus us situation or
you know try and overlay a racial tone
to it because I don't believe that that
is the case the minister believes the
rioters anger was fueled by alcohol a
proposal to set up alcohol
free zones in Little India has been on
the table for some time but he now wants
them to be made even tougher
others say Singapore's South Asian
foreign workers must be given fairer
terms and better pay this they say will
go a long way towards removing tensions
which could threaten Singapore's
reputation as a safe and stable Society
ashleen BBC News Singapore
